elements.content: Purification of ethylene by removing acetylene from an ethylene/acetylene (99/1 v/v) mixture is a challenging task in the petrochemical industry. Our effort toward finding new porous materials that can selectively uptake acetylene resulted in two 3D metal–organic frameworks. Compound 1, {[Zn­(p-pda)­(bpee)]} (p-pda = p-phenylenediacetate and bpee = 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene) turned out to be a nonporous structure due to the presence of a bulky and rigid aromatic ring in the p-pda ligand. Interestingly, replacement of p-pda with succinic acid yields the microporous framework {[Zn2(μ 3-OH)­(suc)1.5(bpee)]·CH3OH·2H2O} (2; suc = succinate), which offers a 1D channel along the a direction occupied by guest methanol and water molecules. Remarkably, the desolvated framework of 2 shows selective uptake of C2H2 over other gas molecules such as C2H4, C2H6, CO2 and CH4 at 293 K. An ideal absorbed solution theory (IAST) study predicts a high selectivity value for acetylene adsorption over the other gas molecules mentioned above. The efficiency of removal of acetylene from ethylene/acetylene mixtures containing 1% acetylene was established through a column breakthrough experiment performed at room temperature. The performance of our material in the purification of ethylene by removing acetylene is comparable with those reported in the literature. In the frameworks of both 1 and 2, the ethylenic double bonds of adjacent bpee linkers are aligned parallel and readily undergo [2 + 2] cycloaddition reactions upon UV-light irradiation to yield {[Zn2(p-pda)2(rctt-tpcb)]} (1IR) and {[Zn4(μ3-OH)2(suc)3(rctt-tpcb)]·2CH3OH·4H2O} (2IR), respectively (rctt-tpcb = regio-cis,trans,trans-tetrakis­(4-pyridyl)­cyclobutane). Photochemical structural transformations of 100% were observed in single-crystal to single-crystal fashions, which were also supported by 1H NMR spectroscopy. The structures of both 2 and 2IR underwent temperature-dependent reversible structural transformations, which was confirmed by SCXRD and DSC analysis. Selective C2H2 uptake of the dehydrated framework of 2IR was also examined, which demonstrates results similar to those of 2.

elements.content: Ethylene, an important monomeric organic feedstock in the petroleum industry, is prepared by the steam cracking of naphtha or other hydrocarbons such as ethane and propane at temperatures between 750 and 900 °C. A small amount of acetylene as an impurity of about 1% is also produced during this process. The presence of acetylene at a level of more than 5 ppm can act as a poison to the PdII catalysts used for the synthesis of important industrial chemicals out of the ethylene feedstock. Moreover, the formation of solid metal acetylides at a high temperature can also lead toward explosion by blocking the fluid steam. Therefore, it is a great challenge to the ethylene producer and catalyst manufacturer to remove the trace amount of acetylene from an acetylene/ethylene mixture (1/99 v/v).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
Ethylene, an important
monomeric organic feedstock in the petroleum
industry, is prepared by the steam cracking of naphtha or other hydrocarbons
such as ethane and propane at temperatures between 750 and 900 °C.
A small amount of acetylene as an impurity of about 1% is also produced
during this process. The presence of acetylene at a level of more
than 5 ppm can act as a poison to the PdII catalysts used
for the synthesis of important industrial chemicals out of the ethylene
feedstock. Moreover, the formation of
solid metal acetylides at a high temperature can also lead toward
explosion by blocking the fluid steam. Therefore, it is a great challenge to the ethylene producer and
catalyst manufacturer to remove the trace amount of acetylene from
an acetylene/ethylene mixture (1/99 v/v).

elements.content: The current acetylene removal methods such as cryogenic distillation are energy-consuming and hence are found to be costly processes. In this regard, use of the emerging microporous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) in the implementation of pressure swing adsorption (PSA), temperature swing adsorption (TSA), and adsorbent-based membrane devices could reduce the cost of separating acetylene from its mixture with ethylene. Gas adsorption and/or separations based on MOFs have been of special interest to materials chemists for the past two decades. The unique advantage of microporous MOFs as adsorbents over traditional porous materials (such as zeolite materials) is their modular nature, where the tuning of the pore structure to achieve a size-selective sieving effect is very straightforward and rational. High selectivity for one particular gas molecule over others can be achieved in microporous MOFs by tuning the pore size (molecular sieving based separation) or by introducing specific interaction sites in the pore surface through pre- or postsynthetic linker modification. The M′-MOF series, reported by Chen et al., reveals high acetylene selectivity, though the amount of uptake is much less in comparison to the MOF-74 series due to their narrow pore window. On the other hand, despite showing high uptake, the MOF-74 series shows poor C2H2/C2H4 selectivity due to the similar affinity of the UMSs toward both gases.

The current
acetylene removal methods such as cryogenic distillation
are energy-consuming and hence are found to be costly processes. In this regard, use of the emerging microporous metal–organic
frameworks (MOFs) in the implementation of pressure swing adsorption
(PSA), temperature swing adsorption (TSA), and adsorbent-based membrane
devices could reduce the cost of separating acetylene from its mixture
with ethylene. Gas adsorption and/or separations based on MOFs have been of special
interest to materials chemists for the past two decades. The unique advantage of microporous MOFs as adsorbents over traditional
porous materials (such as zeolite materials) is their modular nature,
where the tuning of the pore structure to achieve a size-selective
sieving effect is very straightforward and rational. High selectivity for one particular gas molecule over others can
be achieved in microporous MOFs by tuning the pore size (molecular
sieving based separation) or by introducing specific interaction sites
in the pore surface through pre- or postsynthetic linker modification. The M′-MOF series, reported by Chen et al., reveals high
acetylene selectivity, though the amount of uptake is much less in
comparison to the MOF-74 series due to their narrow pore window. On the other hand, despite showing high uptake,
the MOF-74 series shows poor C2H2/C2H4 selectivity due to the similar affinity of the UMSs
toward both gases.

elements.content: Therefore, for the achievement of this challenging task, an ideal MOF material should be decked with both narrow pore channels to maximize the sieving effects for high separation selectivity and a pore window of moderate size to improve C2H2 uptake capacity. Recently, we have achieved kinetic-based separation by controlling the window dimension or pore size of MOFs and also demonstrated separation on the basis of favorable thermodynamic interactions of the specific adsorbate molecules with the pore surface. The performance of this material encouraged us to seek new porous materials which have similar pore architectures for exceptionally efficient C2H2 selectivity in a cost-effective way. Herein, we report the synthesis of the two coordination polymers {[Zn­(p-pda)­(bpee)]} (1) and {[Zn2(μ3-OH)­(suc)1.5(bpee)]·CH3OH·2H2O} (2) (bpee = 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene, p-pda = p-phenylenediacetate, and suc = succinate). The desolvated framework of compounds 2 shows excellent selectivity for C2H2 over C2H4 and C2H6.

elements.content: The combination of various interaction sites with the presence of narrow 1D pore channels maximizes the sieving effect for the removal of C2H2 from C2H2/C2H4 mixtures, which has also been experimentally established through column breakthrough measurements under ambient conditions. A photoinduced [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction is a popular choice for postsynthetic modification (PSM) aimed toward the alteration of the size and polarity of the pore surface in porous coordination polymers. The exo-bidentate organic spacer 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (bpee) is one of the preferred organic linkers for investigating topochemical cycloaddition reactions, and several [2 + 2] cycloaddition reactions in coordination polymers have been reported. The parallel arrangement of the two adjacent bpee linkers in compounds 1 and 2 furnishes a rare opportunity to study the cycloaddition of −CC– bonds in 3D coordination polymer (). Upon illuminating single crystals of 1 and 2 with UV light, [2 + 2] cycloaddition reactions occur between the adjacent pairs of olefinic bonds to form a cyclobutane ring in the irradiated compounds {[Zn2(p-pda)2(rctt-tpcb)]} (1IR) and {[Zn4(μ3-OH)2(suc)3(rctt-tpcb)]·2CH3OH·4H2O} (2IR); (rctt-tpcb = regio-cis,trans,trans-tetrakis­(4-pyridyl)­cyclobutane).

elements.content: All of the reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and were used as supplied without further purification. Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O, 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (bpee), succinic acid (H2 suc) and p-phenylenediacetic acid (H2(p-pda)) were obtained from the Aldrich Chemical Co.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Details
Materials
All of the reagents and solvents employed
were commercially available and were used as supplied without further
purification. Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O,
1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (bpee), succinic acid (H2 suc)
and p-phenylenediacetic acid (H2(p-pda)) were obtained from the Aldrich Chemical Co.

elements.content: An aqueous solution (10 mL) of sodium p-phenylenediacetate (1 mmol, 0.238 g) was mixed with a methanolic solution (10 mL) of 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (bpee; 1 mmol, 0.184 g) and stirred for 10 min for uniform mixing. Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol, 0.298 g) was dissolved in 20 mL of water, and 2 mL of the metal solution was placed in a crystal tube. After that, the mixed ligand solution (2 mL) was slowly and carefully layered over the metal solution assisted by 2 mL of buffer solution (1/1 water/methanol). The crystal tube was sealed and kept undisturbed at room temperature to keep the different solvent layers intact. Transparent block-shaped single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained on the walls of the tube after 2 weeks. The crystals were separated, washed with a methanol/water (1/1) mixture, and dried in air (yield 71% based on ZnII). The phase purity was confirmed by PXRD (Figure S13) and 1H NMR (400 MHz, DCl/d 6-DMSO) spectroscopy (Figure S2). Anal. Calcd for C22H18N2O4Zn: C, 60.08; H, 4.13; N, 6.37. Found: C, 60.25; H, 4.26; N, 6.12. IR (KBr, cm–1): νas(COO) 1617; νs(COO) 1365; ν­(Ar­(C–H)) 2945, 2819; ν­(Ar­(CC)) 1639, 1527 (Figure S1).

Synthesis of {Zn­(p-pda)­(bpee)} (1)
An aqueous solution (10 mL) of sodium p-phenylenediacetate (1 mmol, 0.238 g) was mixed with a methanolic
solution (10 mL) of 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (bpee; 1 mmol, 0.184
g) and stirred for 10 min for uniform mixing. Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol, 0.298 g) was dissolved in 20
mL of water, and 2 mL of the metal solution was placed in a crystal
tube. After that, the mixed ligand solution (2 mL) was slowly and
carefully layered over the metal solution assisted by 2 mL of buffer
solution (1/1 water/methanol). The crystal tube was sealed and kept
undisturbed at room temperature to keep the different solvent layers
intact. Transparent block-shaped single crystals suitable for X-ray
diffraction analysis were obtained on the walls of the tube after
2 weeks. The crystals were separated, washed with a methanol/water
(1/1) mixture, and dried in air (yield 71% based on ZnII). The phase purity was confirmed by PXRD (Figure S13) and 1H NMR (400 MHz, DCl/d
6-DMSO) spectroscopy (Figure S2). Anal. Calcd for C22H18N2O4Zn: C, 60.08; H, 4.13; N, 6.37. Found: C, 60.25; H, 4.26;
N, 6.12. IR (KBr, cm–1): νas(COO)
1617; νs(COO) 1365; ν­(Ar­(C–H)) 2945,
2819; ν­(Ar­(CC)) 1639, 1527 (Figure S1).

elements.content: Compound 1IR was prepared by irradiating compound 1 with UV light (365 nm) with laser light (with an average ultraviolet light intensity of 10500 mW/cm2) by Hamamatsu, Japan. Good-quality single crystals from the crystal tube were placed in a glass Petri dish and irradiated with UV light for 5 min. To assure 100% photoreaction, the crystals were turned upside down under the microscope, and the irradiation was continued for another 5 min. After the photoirradiation, the best single crystal was selected and mounted on a glass fiber for single-crystal X-ray diffraction data collection. Before the photoreaction of the bulk powder sample, compound 1 was continuously ground for 5 min. Then the powder sample was sandwiched between a pair of quartz glass plates and irradiated for 2 h. During the photoreaction, the sample was mixed properly every 15 min for uniform exposure of crystallites to UV rays. This also ensures the necessary cooling of the UV source. A 5−8 mg portion of the sample of 1/1IR was placed in a a beaker, and 4 mL of DCl was added to digest the framework. The solution was then heated on a hot plate at 120 °C to give a dry powder which was again dissolved by adding 4 mL of DMSO-d 6. The resulting solution was transferred to an NMR tube using a syringe, and 1H NMR analysis was carried out for this solution. The phase purity was confirmed by PXRD (Figure S13) and 1H NMR (400 MHz, DCl/d 6-DMSO) spectroscopy (Figure S3). Anal. Calcd for C44H36N4O8Zn2: C, 60.08; H, 4.13; N, 6.37. Found: C, 60.14; H, 4.23; N, 6.32. IR (KBr, cm–1): νas(COO) 1618; νs(COO) 1353; ν­(Ar­(C–H)) 2983, 2874; ν­(Ar­(CC)) 1683, 1553 (Figure S1).

After 10 days transparent block-shaped single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained on the walls of the tube. elements.content: The elemental analyses of each compound and their corresponding desolvated phases were carried out on a Thermo Fisher Flash 2000 Elemental Analyzer. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopic studies were carried out using KBr pellets (Bruker IFS-66v). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out (Mettler Toledo) under a nitrogen atmosphere (flow rate 50 mL min–1) in the temperature range 30–700 °C (heating rate 5 °C min–1). Differential scanning calorimetric studies were carried in the temperature range of 150–313 K by using a TA DSC Q2000 instrument. Powder XRD patterns of the products were recorded by using Cu Kα radiation (Bruker D8 Discover; 40 kV, 30 mA). 1H NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker AV-400 spectrometer with chemical shifts reported in ppm (in DCl/d 6-DMSO, TMS as internal standard).

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of compounds 1, 1IR, 2 and 2IR were mounted on thin glass fibers with commercially available Super Glue. X-ray single-crystal structural data were collected on a Bruker D8 VENTURE instrument with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) operating at 50 kV and 1 mA. The program SAINT was used for the integration of diffraction profiles, and absorption correction was made with the SADABS program. All of the structures were solved by SHELXLT and refined by full-matrix least-squared methodd using SHELXL 2018. All of the hydrogen atoms were fixed by HFIX and placed in ideal positions. The potential solvent-accessible area or void space was calculated using the PLATON multipurpose crystallographic software. All crystallographic and structure refinement data of 1, 1IR, 2 (RT), 2 (LT), 2IR (RT), and 2IR (LT) are summarized in Table S1. All calculations were carried out using SHELXL 2018, PLATON, and the WinGX system, Ver. 1.80.05.

elements.content: A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with P21/n space group. The structure of compound 1 contains the basic centrosymmetric dimeric secondary building unit (SBU) [Zn2(COO)4N4] with highly distorted octahedral ZnII metal center (a). The Zn···Zn distance in the dimeric SBU is 4.043(3) Å. The equatorial positions of ZnII octahedra are occupied by four oxygen atoms; two of them are from the chelating carboxylate group (O3 and O4) and other two (O1 and O2) are from two different carboxylates which bridge two ZnII centers in the [Zn2(COO)4N4] dimeric SBU. Two nitrogen atoms from two different bpee ligands are ligated in the axial positions to complete the distorted-octahedral coordination sphere. The Zn–O­(carboxylate) bond lengths in 1 range from 2.021(2) to 2.385(3) Å, and the Zn–N pyridyl bond lengths are 2.171(3) and 2.186(3) Å, respectively. In compound 1, one carboxylate group of the pda ligand connected two ZnII centers in a syn,syn bridging mode, whereas the other carboxylate group chelated with one of the ZnII centers of an adjacent dimeric unit (b). The [Zn2(COO)4N4] SBUs are interconnected through −CH2C6H4CH2– tethers of the PDA linker, forming a 2D layer extended along the (10–1)­plane (b). The 2D layer has a (44.62) topology based on 4-connected dinuclear ZnII nodes and PDA linkers. Along the c direction, two successive 2D layers are bipillared by the bpee ligand to construct a 3D architecture of compound 1 (d). Examination with TOPOS revealed that compound 1 is a trinodal (2-c)­(3-c)­(5-c) periodic 3D net formed by two different types of 2- and 3-connected phenylenediacetate (pda) and a 5-connected dimeric Zn SBU (Figure S7a). Further examination showed that 1 adopts a network topology with the Schläfli symbol {4.82}­{4.88.12}. It is worth mentioning that a 3D structure based on pda and 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethane linkers with a topology similar to that of 1 was reported by Sezer et al.

elements.content: The dimeric SBU of compound 1 facilitates the parallel orientation of two bpee molecules where they can obey Schmidt’s photochemical criteria. The pyridyl parts of the bpee ligands are also aligned parallel with strong π···π interactions with a center to center distance of 3.98 Å (e). A single crystal of compound 1 was irradiated for 10 min with 365 nm laser light, and single crystal data were collected at 298 K. The single-crystal structure determination of compound 1IR showed that the framework structure almost remains unchanged. The distance between the two successive 2D layers (through Zn1–Zn2a; (a) −x, 2 – y, 1 – z) along the newly formed 4,4′-rctt-tpcb linker is 13.481(3) Å, which is shorter than the distance through the bpee pillar in the as-synthesized compound (13.719(4) Å). The distance between the adjacent metal centers (Zn1 and Zn1a) in the SBU has increased from 4.043 to 4.321 Å (e,f). The newly formed C–C single-bond distance is 1.6 Å, which strongly affirms the formation of C–C single bonds. Compound 1IR is also a trinodal (3-c)2(4-c)­(5-c)2 periodic net formed by 3-connected phenylenediacetate (pda), a 4-connected newly formed tpcb linker, and a 5-connected dimeric Zn SBU (Figure S7b). Further examination shows that 1IR adopts an unprecedented network topology with the Schläfli symbol {4.82}2{42.84}­{46.84}2.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic system with P 1 space group. The asymmetric unit of 2 contains two crystallographically independent ZnII ions (Zn1 and Zn2), one and a half succinates, one bpee linker, one hydroxyl anion, two guest water molecules and one guest methanol molecule (a). A structure determination confirmed the presence of a secondary building unit (SBU) constructed by the zinc hydroxyl carboxylate cluster {Zn4(μ3-OH)2(COO)6N4} (b). In the asymmetric unit, the ZnII center (Zn1) showed a distorted-tetrahedral geometry with a ZnO3N core. Each Zn1 is coordinated with two different carboxylate oxygen atoms (O4 and O5c; (c) 2 – x, 2 – y, 1 – z), one μ3-bridging hydroxyl group oxygen (O7) and one pyridyl nitrogen atom (N1) of bpee (Zn1–O bond lengths are in the range of 1.926(3)–1.980(3) Å, and the Zn1–N bond length is 2.033(3) Å). The other ZnII (Zn2) center is in a distorted-octahedral geometry with a ZnO5N core. The coordination of the Zn2 metal center is furnished by three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2, O3b, and O6b; (b) −1 + x, y, z) of three different succinates, two O atoms from μ3-bridging hydroxyl groups (O7 and O7a; (a) 1 – x, 2 – y, 1 – z), and one pyridyl nitrogen atom (N2) of one bpee ligand (b). The Zn2–O bond lengths lie in the range of 2.049(3)–2.185(2) Å, and the Zn2–N bond length is 2.132(3) Å. Each tetranuclear SBU cluster {Zn4(μ3-OH)2(COO)6N4} is composed of two scalene triangles (formed by the three ZnII metal ions Zn2–Zn2–Zn1)) which share two symmetry-related ZnII ions (Zn2 and Zn2a) as the base (b). The μ3-bridging hydroxyl group oxygen (O7) is present above the triangular plane, forming Zn1–O7–Zn2, Zn1–O7–Zn2a, and Zn2–O7–Zn2a angles of 130.77(11), 100.06(11), and 96.63(10)°, respectively. Two consecutive tetranuclear SBUs are connected by the eclipsed-succinic acid (O3, O4, O5, and O6 of SUC-A; c) through the Zn1 and Zn2 centers, which are further extended along the a direction to form a 1D chain. These 1D chains are interconnected with each other through the carboxylate oxygen atom (O2) of staggered-succinic acid (SUC-B) to generate a 2D layer along the ab plane (e). The formation of the 3D architecture of compound 2 is constructed by the connection of two successive 2D layers along the c direction through the N,N′ linear linker 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (bpee; N1 and N2) (a). The rectangular-shaped 1D channel occupied by guest water and methanol molecules has the dimensions of 7.2 × 3.7 Å2 (b). Compound 2 offers a free space of 218.4 Å3, which is 18.9% with respect to unit cell volume. An examination with TOPOS reveals that compound 2 is a trinodal (2-c)4(2-c)­(10-c) periodic 3D net formed by two different types of 2-connected succinates and a 10-connected tetranuclear Zn SBU (Figure S8a). Further examination shows that 2 adopts an unprecedented network topology with the Schläfli symbol {44.832.129}4. It is very interesting to note that the olefinic double bonds of adjacent bpee pairs are aligned parallel with the support of the Zn1–O7–Zn2 unit, where the distance between the centers of CC bonds is 3.87 Å (a). The pyridyl parts of the bpee ligands are also aligned parallel with strong π···π interactions with a center to center distance of 4.0 Å. This geometry is ideal for a topochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction in the solid state as postulated by Schmidt.

elements.content: A single-crystal structure determination of compound 2LT showed that it retains its crystal symmetry similarly to that of compound 2 at 140 K. However, interestingly we observed that one axis is exactly double in comparison to the cell parameters collected at 293 K. A detailed structural analysis showed that the orientations of the olefinic groups in bpee molecules connecting the Zn1 and Zn2 centers of two adjacent layers are similar, as shown in a. However, at low temperature, due to the change in orientation of one olefinic group (see a, molecule presented in yellow) the symmetry between the two bpee molecules breaks and hence the crystallographic axis was found to be twice that of the room temperature structure. Therefore, compounds 2 and 2LT can be related as polymorphs, where a temperature-driven phase change was observed. To prove this, we performed a DSC analysis of compound 2 (b) in the temperature range of 150–313 K; we observed an exothermic peak with a maximum at 278 K. The corresponding ΔH value is 2.19 kJ/mol, suggesting much less energy involved in this polymorphic phase transition. The single-crystal data of the irradiated compound collected at low temperature also demonstrates a similar kind of phase transition.

elements.content: A single-crystal structure determination of compound 2IR shows that the framework structure almost remains unchanged except for the formation of new C–C bonds across the olefinic bonds between the parallel bpee ligands along the c direction (d). The newly formed C–C single-bond distance is 1.6 Å, which is comparable to that of a normal C–C single bond. The distance between the two successive 2D layers (through Zn1–Zn2d; (d) −x, 1 – y, −z) along the newly formed 4,4′-rctt tpcb linker is 13.315(3) Å, which is shorter than the distance through the bpee pillar in the as-synthesized compound (13.520(4) Å). The distance between the adjacent metal centers (Zn1 and Zn2) in the SBU has increased from 3.614(2) to 3.703(3) Å. The structural contraction is also reflected from the reduced cell volume, where it decreased from 1156 to 1110 Å3 after the photoreaction (Table S1). A comparative image is given in Figure S9 in the Supporting Information, which demonstrates the movement of the pyridine ring of the bpee ligand due to the formation of the cyclobutane ring. The dimerization reaction also results in a decrease of the total solvent-accessible area, which is reflected in the reduced void space from 18.9% to 14.6% with respect to unit cell volume. Compound 2IR is also a trinodal (2-c)2(2-c)2(8-c) periodic net formed by 2-connected succinates (suc), 2-connected newly formed tpcb linkers, and an 8-connected tetranuclear Zn SBU (Figure S8b). Further examination shows that 2IR adopts an unprecedented network topology with the Schläfli symbol {42.820.126}2.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out to study the stability of the frameworks. TGA of all the compounds was performed in the temperature range 30–700 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere. In the case of 1 and 1IR, the compounds are stable up to 250 °C without showing any step (Figure S10). The TGA profile of 2 (Figure S11) indicates a weight loss of 11.21% at 100 °C, which corroborates the removal of guest (one methanol and two water) molecules (calcd 11.89%). The desolvated framework is stable up to 205 °C. After that, it gradually decomposes into unidentified products. A similar profile was also obtained for 2IR (Figure S12). The PXRD patterns of all the compounds in different states are shown in and Figure S13. In all of the compounds good correspondence of the different peak positions in the simulated and as-synthesized patterns suggests the phase purity of the as-synthesized compounds. In the cases of 2a and 2IRa, the similarity between the PXRD patterns of as-synthesized and heated samples indicate that there is no significant structural change upon desolvation. Even after exposure to water vapor for 15 days, the structure of the rehydrated samples remained intact, as evidenced by the PXRD patterns. This suggested that the framework is stable in the presence of water vapor.

elements.content: Removal of guest methanol and water molecules offers a 1D channel along the a direction, which encouraged us to study the permanent porosity and storage capacity of compound 2. The desolvated framework of 2 (i.e., 2a) was found to be nonporous with respect to N2 (77 K) and CO2 (273 K) (Figures S14 and S15). The nonporous nature may be attributed to the smaller aperture size of the 1D channel in comparison to the kinetic diameter of N2 (3.64 Å) as well as the low kinetic energy of the N2 molecules at low temperature (77 K), which results in N2 molecules being unable to enter effectively into the pores.
elements.clean_text:
Probing the Porous Properties
Removal of guest methanol
and water molecules offers a 1D channel along the a direction, which encouraged us to study the permanent porosity and
storage capacity of compound 2. The desolvated framework
of 2 (i.e., 2a) was found to be nonporous
with respect to N2 (77 K) and CO2 (273 K) (Figures S14 and S15). The nonporous nature may
be attributed to the smaller aperture size of the 1D channel in comparison
to the kinetic diameter of N2 (3.64 Å) as well as
the low kinetic energy of the N2 molecules at low temperature
(77 K), which results in N2 molecules being unable to enter
effectively into the pores.

elements.content: The window size (7.2 × 3.7 Å2) of the 1D channel present in compound 2a further encouraged us to probe the adsorption property of C2 hydrocarbons having kinetic diameters similar to the pore size (C2H2 3.3 Å, C2H4 4.2 Å and C2H6 4.5 Å). Interestingly, at 293 K, the desolvated framework only allows the inclusion of C2H2 gas (3.10 wt %; 27 mL/g), while it completely excludes other small molecules such as CO2 (0.46 wt %; 3 mL/g), CH4 (0.18 wt %; 2 mL/g), C2H4 (0.26 wt %; 5 mL/g), and C2H6 (0.13 wt %; 3.5 mL/g) (a). A similar type of selective gas uptake was also documented in the case of the irradiated compound 2IRa, where the final C2H2 uptake was found to be 2.27 wt % (20 mL/g) (b). The lesser amount of C2H2 uptake by 2IR in comparison to 2 is due to the overall shrinkage of the framework along with the decrease in void volume after the photoreaction (Figure S24). To better understand the interactions between C2H2 and the desolvated frameworks (2a and 2IRa), we have calculated the zero coverage isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) using a virial equation (adsorption data collected at 283 and 293 K; details are given in Figures S16 and S17 in the Supporting Information). As shown in c, the zero coverage isosteric heats of adsorption were calculated to be 27 and 29 kJ mol–1 for 2a and 2IRa, respectively. Interestingly, the binding energy values for both compounds are decreasing with an increase in pressure, which implies that the regeneration energy requirement of compound 2a would be much less under ambient conditions. The higher acetylene adsorption capacity in comparison with the other C2 hydrocarbons indicates that the compounds are an attractive material for the selective adsorptive-based separation of acetylene from the three-gas mixture. The stronger interaction between C2H2 and the MOF surface is also reflected in the selectivity estimation of C2H2 over other hydrocarbons employing the IAST model (ideal adsorbed solution theory; details are given in Figures S18–S23 in the Supporting Information) (d). Applying the IAST on pure component isotherms, we have determined the adsorption selectivity of the binary gas mixture of C2H2/C2H4 (1/99 v/v), C2H2/C2H6 (50/50 v/v), and C2H2/CH4 (50/50 v/v) (d). We have used the Langmuir–Freundlich equation to obtain a perfect fit over the single-component isotherms, and the obtained precise fitting parameters were employed to accurately perform the necessary integrations (see the Supporting Information for details of the calculation). The IAST-predicted binary gas mixture selectivities of C2H2 over C2H4, C2H6, and CH4 are 7, 22, and 7, respectively, whereas those for the irradiated compound (2IRa) are 28, 18, and 7 at 100 kPa (d), which are comparable with values found in other reports ().

The experimental separation ability of any solid adsorbents is determined by the kinetic study of a particular gas under a constant mixed gas flow. We have chosen 2a as a prototype material for its higher acetylene uptake capacity at 293 K. The aptitude of compound 2a in the actual adsorption-based separation and purification process of acetylene from C2H2/C2H4 mixtures was examined through an experimental column breakthrough measurement. In this experiment, a C2H2/C2H4 (1/99, v/v) gas mixture flowed through a packed column of 2a with a total flow of 2.2 mL min–1 at 293 K. The gas flow was controlled by a mass flow controller (MFC), and the gas at the outlet was collected and examined through a GC instrument. The efficient separation of C2H2 from the gas mixture through a breakthrough measurement has been successfully achieved, as depicted in e. The adsorption and separation data for 2a and some reported MOFs are given in . The unsaturated metal sites of the MOF-74 series render high acetylene uptake, whereas their selectivity of C2H2 over C2H4 is enormously reduced due to the presence of the equal affinity of the metal centers toward both gas molecules. In this regard, compound 2a has multiple weak supramolecular interactions aligned within the host, which harvests an optimal geometry for the selective binding of acetylene under ambient conditions (f). On the basis of the above discussion, it is clear that rather than the presence of unsaturated metal sites (UMSs), optimal pore engineering for achieving a high sieving effect can provide a better recognition for acetylene by a MOF.

elements.content: In summary, we have designed and synthesized two 3D metal–organic frameworks based on a mixed linker system. With succinate and bpee, a 3D framework with 1D channel was realized in compound 2, whereas the use of the flexible linker p-phenylenediacetate (p-pda) resulted in a 3D nonporous structure (1). The parallel arrangement of the photoactive bpee linkers in 1 and 2 facilitates a topochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction in both frameworks in a single-crystal to single-crystal transformation fashion. Temperature-dependent structural polymorphism was observed in the case of 2. We have showed selective adsorption of C2H2 by 2 and 2IR among other gases such as C2H4, C2H6, and CH4 under ambient conditions. This selectivity for C2H2 has been further exploited by a breakthrough measurement of the gas mixture C2H2/C2H4 (1/99 v/v). Such a high selectivity and separation capacity can be attributed to the perfect window size of the 1D pore in compound 2, where C2H2 molecules can easily diffuse and strongly interact with pores decorated with an aromatic π cloud. In contrast, the other small molecules with kinetic diameter relatively higher than that of C2H2 cannot enter into the 1D channel. This work may initiate more extensive studies on the size- and shape-controlled selective separation of small hydrocarbons which will essentially pave the way for the synthesis of future novel high-performance adsorption base separating materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion
In summary, we have designed
and synthesized two 3D metal–organic
frameworks based on a mixed linker system. With succinate and bpee,
a 3D framework with 1D channel was realized in compound 2, whereas the use of the flexible linker p-phenylenediacetate
(p-pda) resulted in a 3D nonporous structure (1). The parallel arrangement of the photoactive bpee linkers
in 1 and 2 facilitates a topochemical [2
+ 2] cycloaddition reaction in both frameworks in a single-crystal
to single-crystal transformation fashion. Temperature-dependent structural
polymorphism was observed in the case of 2. We have showed
selective adsorption of C2H2 by 2 and 2IR among other gases such as C2H4, C2H6, and CH4 under ambient
conditions. This selectivity for C2H2 has been
further exploited by a breakthrough measurement of the gas mixture
C2H2/C2H4 (1/99 v/v).
Such a high selectivity and separation capacity can be attributed
to the perfect window size of the 1D pore in compound 2, where C2H2 molecules can easily diffuse and
strongly interact with pores decorated with an aromatic π cloud.
In contrast, the other small molecules with kinetic diameter relatively
higher than that of C2H2 cannot enter into the
1D channel. This work may initiate more extensive studies on the size-
and shape-controlled selective separation of small hydrocarbons which
will essentially pave the way for the synthesis of future novel high-performance
adsorption base separating materials.
